nodes.bodyText: Refresh design is outlined here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GYIyEhJQ3ngvOPmJYWU-8zwDQRCMXkBDZaSn3c3MF0k/edit# , please ignore the open question here.
There's a major revamp of the planner on the way, so you may want to rebase on that change to avoid conflicts later on: #3600
ok, will do. Temporarily turning the PR to 'Draft' to make frequent changes and ensure that tests pass. Thanks.
Hi Martin, I rebased this code on top of PR #3600 and is also rebased on top of master. Can you please give it a look? Thanks.
Place each argument on a separate line when splitting across multiple lines.
This method is a no-op. The !finalProperties.containsKey(entry.getKey()) will cause every entry from defaultProperties to be copied to the result map. It's equivalent to just returning the input map.
yes, you are right. Fixed.
Why both?
Also, permissions are being checked in the analyzer, as well, so this is redundant

You are right, the permissions are being checked in Analyzer. So, I will remove this code.
I think here is how access checks should be done (current code is not complete/correct .. will fix).

StatementAnalyzer:visitCreateMaterializedView:

Check 'canCreateView' with materialized view name as parameter
Check 'canCreateTable' with storage table name as parameter


DropMaterializedViewTask:execute:

Check 'canDropView' with materialized view name as parameter
check 'canDropTable' with storage table name as parameter


Refresh materialized view is broken into delete/insert etc .. so those commands perform access control checks.
What do you think?

That makes sense. We need to make sure the refresh actions execute with the permissions of the owner of the materialized view. We need to consider how that will work, if at all, for credential pass-through.

We talked offline about credential passthrough. It does not work as expected for views as well and materialized views emulate the view design. So, for now, we will document that credential passthrough is not supported with materialized views.
No need to wrap arguments here.

nodes.bodyText: No need to wrap arguments here
No need to wrap arguments here
SECURITY INVOKER doesn't make sense for materialized views. They need to run with DEFINER mode always, so let's just get rid of this

+        (IF NOT EXISTS)?
+        qualifiedName
+        (SECURITY (DEFINER | INVOKER))?

nodes.bodyText:
Enhance the message to say:
'writerTarget must be CreateTarget, InsertTarget or RefreshMVTarget'
This shouldn't be a rewrite (actually, rewrites are a bit of a mis-feature). Instead, it should go through analysis and planning, similar to how views are resolved and expanded.
Done.
Don't use abbreviations. Cal this RefreshMaterializedView
Got it. Renamed all 'RefreshMV' classes to 'RefreshMaterializedView'. Variable names still use abbreviations.

The node should be a reflection of the query syntax. As such, the Query has no place here, since it's not something that would be typed as part of the REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW xxx command. I understand why you added it, but see my comment in RefreshMaterializedViewRewrite for how to approach it.
Got it.
Rename notExists to ignoreExisting
Done

What does AbstractMap.SimpleEntry<Boolean, Optional<String>> represent? Consider adding a dedicated holder object for that concept instead of using AbstractMap.SimpleEntry, which is supposed to represent at key-value pair for a map.

nodes.bodyText: Place each argument on a separate line when splitting across multiple lines.
Hmm, my version of code here shows each argument on a separate line. Are you seeing something else?
Don't abbreviate the variable name.
Done
Do not abbreviate variable names.
done
I'd suggest naming this RefreshMaterializedViewAnalysis
Done
Don't abbreviate variable names (optionalMatView). Just call it optionalView
done
node isn't used.
Removed 'node'
optionalMatView -> optionalView (avoid abbreviations)
done
This can be declared below where the assignment is made. I would just get rid of the variable altogether, though and inline it in the return call.
right. done.
private
done
Done

getProperties().getOrDefault("storage_table", "") should be a proper attribute of ConnectorMaterializedViewDefinition. Storing it and accessing it as a dynamic property is brittle. Also, it might conflict with properties defined by the connector.
I agree. Added it as an attribute,
schema is not used below. I belive viewExpandedText is being passed incorrectly in the position of catalog, and catalog is being passed in the position of schema.

Sorry, I made a local change as I was testing with Iceberg connector and forgot to push. The correct call looks like:
super(originalSql, catalog, schema, columns, comment, owner, false);

I don't think we should model materialized views as subtypes of ConnectorViewDefinition. They are separate entities (despite their name) with their own characteristics and behaviors that don't necessarily line up with views.
Yes, I made the change now.
What's viewExpandedText?
Leftover from when materialized views extended views. Removed now.
These probably need to be "delimited" (new Identifier(..., true)) to avoid issues with case sensitivity or ambiguities.
Done

There's nothing specific about "materialized view storage table" in this method -- it could work for any table. Since it's a rather trivial method, it's used in just one place, and it doesn't seem specific to materialized views, inline it and remove it.
done
== true is unnecessary
done
Don't abbreviate variable names
done
We already have the storage table handle at this point. No need to roundtrip again via the table name.
I moved the evaluation of 'tableHandle' up and simply assigned 'storageHandle' to 'tableHandle' at this point.
This change doesn't seem necessary.
yes, reverted
Don't abbreviate names. In this case, it could be renamed to just refreshTarget as a concise and to-the-point name.
done
Don't abbreviate variable names
renamed to 'refreshAnalysis'

This looks exactly the same as createInsertPlan, except for that target table handles and a couple of other things. There's probably some opportunity for reuse, especially given the complexity of this method.
I did some refactoring .. let me know what you think.
Unrelated formatting change
reverted
ImmutableList.copyOf()
done
ImmutableList.copyOf()
done
requireNonNull
done

@martint I had proposed that we perform checkCanCreateTable access check on storage table, but storage table name is generated by the connector and is not available at this point in code.
To keep code symmetric, dropMaterializedView also performs the checkCanDropTable check on materialized view.

That's for the case when the user doesn't specify a storage table right? In that case, it's appropriate to not check, since it's expected that the connector will generate a table the user has access to.
For the case where a user specifies a storage table, that should be validated.

Currently syntax does not allow the user to specify the storage table name (even though the extended syntax has the provision to build it in the future). So, I will remove the accessControl.checkCanCreateTable and accessControl.checkCanDropTable checks.
After our offline discussion. We analyze the materialized view and create scope for it similar to a logical view. This also checks for recursive materialized view definitions etc.
First argument should go on the next line
Unrelated formatting change

nodes.bodyText: Why did this method move?
reverted. Sorry, unintentional
As we discussed offline, the freshness check and short-circuiting should be done in the RefreshMaterializedView task class, before we even get to the planner/optimizer.
We discussed offline. In statement analysis we figure out whether refresh should be skipped and if yes, planner plans a no-op plan.
Let's make this more specific: isSkipMaterializedViewRefresh
Renamed the member variable and getter and setter.
First argument should go on the next line
done
One argument per line when breaking across multiple lines
